objects.name: YiSpecter
objects.description: YiSpecter is Apple iOS malware that can download, install and launch arbitrary iOS apps, replace existing apps with those it downloads, hijack other apps’ execution to display advertisements, change Safari’s default search engine, bookmarks and opened pages, and upload device information to a C2 server. It uses tricks to hide its icons from iOS’s SpringBoard, which prevents the user from finding and deleting it. The components also use the same name and logos of system apps to trick iOS power users. [[1]](#1)

objects.name: Dark Comet
objects.description: A Remote Access Trojan (RAT) that allows a user to control the system via a GUI. It has many features which allows a user to use it as administrative remote help tool; however, DarkComet has many features which can be used maliciously. DarkComet is commonly used to spy on the victims by taking screen captures, key-logging, or password stealing. [[1]](#1)

The Malware Behavior Catalog (MBC) is a catalog of malware objectives and behaviors, created to support malware analysis-oriented use cases, such as labeling, similarity analysis, and standardized reporting.
objects.name: MBC
Create UDP Socket
objects.description: A UDP socket is created.

objects.name: 3DES
objects.description: Malware decrypts data encrypted with the 3DES algorithm.

objects.name: Jump Insertion
objects.description: Insert jumps to make analysis visually harder.

objects.name: Standard Compression of Code
objects.description: Uses a standard algorithm to compress the opcode mnemonics.

objects.name: DDNS Domain Connect
objects.description: Connects to dynamic DNS domain.

objects.name: IWebBrowser
objects.description: The IWebBrowser interface exposes methods and properties implemented by the WebBrowser control or implemented by an instance of the InternetExplorer application. Specific methods and properties can be captured: e.g., COMMUNICATION::HTTP Communication::IWebBrowser.get_Document.

objects.name: Location
objects.description: Malware may change or choose the location of itself, another file, or a directory to prevent detection.

objects.name: RC6
objects.description: Malware decrypts data encrypted with the RC6 algorithm.

objects.name: Send Request
objects.description: HTTP client sends request (GET).

objects.name: Software Breakpoints
objects.description: (INT3/0xCC)

objects.name: Extension
objects.description: Malware may change or use a particular file extension to hide a file.

objects.name: Covert Location
objects.description: Malware may hide data or binary files within other files, the registry, etc.

objects.name: Skipjack
objects.description: Malware decrypts data encrypted with the Skipjack block cipher algorithm.

objects.name: Packer Stub
objects.description: A packer stub can generate polymorphic code.

objects.name: Denial of Service
objects.description: Malware may make a network unavailable, for example, by launching a network-based denial of service (DoS) attack.

objects.name: Check for Emulator-related Files
objects.description: Checks whether particular files (e.g., QEMU files) exist.

objects.name: Instruction Testing - RDTSC
objects.description: The execution of certain x86 instructions will result in different values when executed inside of a VM instead of on bare metal. Accordingly, these can be used to detect the execution of the malware in a VM.

objects.name: Hidden Userspace Libraries
objects.description: Hides userspace libraries used by the malware instance. Technique refers to hiding libraries loaded in memory (not disk). For example, a userspace library may be injected into a system process such that memory scanning tools may be prevented from finding them. This technique is different than DLL injection, in which the DLL will continue to show up in process metadata that tracks what is stored in memory. This technique involves clearing that metadata or making it inaccessible to security and inspection tools.

objects.name: Decrypt Data
objects.description: Malware may decrypt data.

objects.name: InternetOpenURL
objects.description: Opens a resource specified by a complete FTP or HTTP URL.

objects.name: Inspect Section Memory Permissions
objects.description: Malware identifies section memory permissions from image section header.

objects.name: Armadillo
objects.description: Uses Armadillo.

objects.name: UDP Client
objects.description: UDP client behavior.

objects.name: Multiple VMs
objects.description: Multiple virtual machines with different architectures (CISC, RISC, etc.) can be used inside of a single executable in order to make reverse engineering even more difficult.

objects.name: Secure Triggers
objects.description: Code and/or data is encrypted until the underlying system satisfies a preselected condition unknown to the analyst (this is a form of Deposited Keys).

objects.name: Executable Stack
objects.description: The stack is made executable.

objects.name: Guard Pages
objects.description: Encrypt blocks of code individually and decrypt temporarily only upon execution.

objects.name: Create Request
objects.description: HTTP client creates request.

objects.name: Ctrl-Alt-Del
objects.description: Malware simulates Ctrl-Alt-Del.

objects.name: Demo Mode
objects.description: Inclusion of a demo binary/mode that is executed when token is absent or not privileged enough.

objects.name: Shadow System Service Dispatch Table Hooking
objects.description: The Shadow System Service Dispatch Table (SSDT) can be hooked similarly to how the SSDT and IAT are hooked. The target of the hooking with the Shadow SSDT is the Windows subsystem (win32k.sys).

objects.name: Drop Code
objects.description: Original file is written to disk then executed. May confuse some sandboxes, especially if the dropped executable must be provided specific arguments and the original dropper is not associated with the drop file(s).

objects.name: Send Heartbeat
objects.description: Heartbeat sent.

objects.name: Delayed Execution
objects.description: Stalling code is typically executed before any malicious behavior. The malware's aim is to delay the execution of the malicious activity long enough so that an automated dynamic analysis system fails to extract the interesting malicious behavior. This method is very similar to ATT&CK's [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion: Time Based Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497/003/) sub-technique.

objects.name: Timing/Date Check
objects.description: Calling GetSystemTime or equiv and only executing code if the current date/hour/minute/second passes some check. Often this is for running only after or only until a specific date. This behavior can be mitigated in non-automated analysis environments.

objects.name: Encrypted Payloads
objects.description: Decryption key is stored external to the executable or never touches the disk.

objects.name: Hook Interrupt
objects.description: Modification of interrupt vector or descriptor tables.

objects.name: Execute Shell Command
objects.description: Execute/run the given command using a built-in program (e.g. cmd.exe, PowerShell, bash). This differs from Start Interactive Shell because the shell process is started only for the received command or set of commands and then exits. There is no loop looking for additional commands while the shell process is still running.

objects.name: Encode File
objects.description: Encode a file on disk, such as an implant's config file.

objects.name: Import Address Table Hooking
objects.description: Malware (e.g. rootkit) modifies a process's import address table (IAT), which stores pointers to imported API functions.

objects.name: Timing/Delay Check
objects.description: Malware may compare time between two points to detect unusual execution, such as the (relative) massive delays introduced by debugging.

objects.name: Destroy Hardware
objects.description: Destroys a physical piece of hardware. For example, malware may cause hardware to overheat.

objects.name: Self Deletion
objects.description: Malware may uninstall itself to avoid detection.

objects.name: Resolve Free Hosting Domain
objects.description: Resolves a free hosting domain (e.g., freeiz.com).

objects.name: Kernel Mode Rootkit
objects.description: Rootkit operates by adding or replacing code in OS, device drivers, loadable kernel modules (LKM). Related to ATT&CK: [Kernel Modules and Extensions](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1547/006/)

objects.name: Process detection - PCAP Utilities
objects.description: Malware can scan for the process name associated with common analysis tools. Wireshark / Dumpcap

objects.name: Encryption
objects.description: A malware sample, file, or other information is encrypted.

objects.name: InternetConnect
objects.description: Opens an FTP or HTTP session for a given site.

objects.name: Create Thread
objects.description: Malware creates a thread.

objects.name: MSDTC
objects.description: The Distributed Transaction Coordinator (MSDTC) coordinates transaction across multiple resource managers (databases, message queues and file systems). This legitimate Microsoft service is part of Windows 2000 and later and can be used to import and load DLLs. Malware may abuse MSDTC to import and load DLLs.

objects.name: Generate Traffic
objects.description: Generate ICMP traffic.

objects.name: WudfIsAnyDebuggerPresent
objects.description: Includes use of WudfIsAnyDebuggerPresent, WudfIsKernelDebuggerPresent, WudfIsUserDebuggerPresent.

objects.name: Check for WINE Version
objects.description: Checks for WINE via the `get_wine_version` function from WINE's `ntdll.dll`.

objects.name: Memory Dump Evasion
objects.description: Malware hinders retrieval and/or discovery of the contents of the physical memory of the system on which the malware instance is executing [[1]](#1).

external_references.description: J. Stuttgen, M. Cohen, Anti-forensic resilient memory acquisition,

objects.name: Install Insecure or Malicious Configuration
objects.description: Malware may install malicious configuration settings or may modify existing configuration settings. For example, malware may change configuration settings associated with security mechanisms to make it difficult to detect or change configuration settings to maintain a foothold on the network.

objects.name: Generate Pseudo-random Sequence
objects.description: The Generate Pseudo-random Sequence microbehavior can be used for a number of purposes. The methods below include specific functions, as well as pseudorandom number generators (PRNG).

objects.name: Resolve
objects.description: Resolves a domain.

objects.name: Encoding-Custom Algorithm
objects.description: A custom algorithm is used to encode a malware sample, file or other information.

objects.name: Encryption Key
objects.description: Malware may import, generate, or otherwise use an encryption key.

objects.name: Instruction Overlap
objects.description: Jump after the first byte of an instruction to confuse disassembler.

objects.name: Mersenne Twister
objects.description: Malware generates a pseudo-random sequence using the Mersenne Twister PRNG.

objects.name: Screen Capture
objects.description: Malware takes screen captures of the desktop.

objects.name: Connect to Server
objects.description: HTTP client connects to HTTP server.

objects.name: Camellia
objects.description: Malware encrypts with the Camellia algorithm.

objects.name: Virtual Machine Detection
objects.description: Detects whether the malware instance is being executed in a virtual machine (VM), such as VMWare. If so, conditional execution selects a benign execution path.

objects.name: Entry Point Obfuscation
objects.description: Obfuscate the entry point of the malware executable.

objects.name: Delete Registry Key
objects.description: Malware deletes a registry key.

objects.name: Create Socket
objects.description: A server or client creates a UDP or TCP socket.

objects.name: Terminate Process
objects.description: Malware terminates a process.

objects.name: IsDebuggerPresent
objects.description: The kernel32!IsDebuggerPresent API function call checks the PEB BeingDebugged flag to see if the calling process is being debugged. It returns 1 if the process is being debugged, 0 otherwise. This is one of the most common ways of debugger detection.

objects.name: Unique Hardware/Firmware Check - I/O Communication Port
objects.description: Malware may check for hardware characteristics unique to being virtualized, allowing the malware to detect the virtual environment. VMware uses virtual I/O ports for communication between the virtual machine and the host operating system to support functionality like copy and paste between the two systems. The port can be queried and compared with a magic number VMXh to identify the use of VMware.

objects.name: Loop Escapes
objects.description: Use SEH or other methods to break out of a loop instead of a conditional jump.

objects.name: Crypto Algorithm
objects.description: A known crypto algorithm is implemented in the code and it is unknown whether it is from a public crypto library.

objects.name: GetTickCount
objects.description: Malware generates a pseudo-random sequence using GetTickCount.

objects.name: Encoding
objects.description: A malware sample, file, or other information is encoded.

objects.name: Process detection - Process Utilities
objects.description: Malware can scan for the process name associated with common analysis tools. ProcessHacker / SysAnalyzer / HookExplorer / SysInspector

objects.name: Stack Canary
objects.description: Similar to the anti-exploitation method of the same name, malware may try to detect mucking with values on the stack.

objects.name: Spamming
objects.description: Malware may use a victim machine to create and send spam.

objects.name: QuickLZ
objects.description: Malware decompresses data using QuickLZ.

objects.name: Manipulate Network Traffic
objects.description: Malware intercepts and manipulates network traffic, typically accessing or modifying data, going to or originating from the system on which the malware instance is executing. Also known as a Man-in-the-Middle attack.

objects.name: MD5
objects.description: Malware uses an MD5 hash.

objects.name: Undocumented Opcodes
objects.description: Use rare or undocumented opcodes to block non-exhaustive emulators.

objects.name: Blowfish
objects.description: Malware encrypts with the Blowfish algorithm.

objects.name: Get File Attributes
objects.description: Malware gets the attributes of a file.

objects.name: COMSPEC Environment Variable
objects.description: Uninstalls self via COMSPEC environment variable.

objects.name: Feed Misinformation
objects.description: API behavior can be altered to prevent memory dumps. For example, inaccurate data can be reported when the contents of the physical memory of the system on which the malware instance is executing is retrieved. See [Hooking](../credential-access/hooking.md).

objects.name: Standard Compression
objects.description: Uses a standard algorithm, such as UPX or LZMA, to compress an executable file.

objects.name: AES
objects.description: Malware decrypts data encrypted with the AES algorithm.

objects.name: Modern Specs Check - Keyboard layout
objects.description: Different aspects of the hardware are inspected to determine whether the machine has modern characteristics. A machine with substandard specifications indicates a virtual environment. Check keyboard layout.

objects.name: Crypto Library
objects.description: Malware uses a crypto library.

objects.name: Timing/Uptime Check
objects.description: Comparing single GetTickCount with some value to see if system has been started at least *X* amount ago. This behavior can be mitigated in non-automated analysis environments.

objects.name: Hook memory mapping APIs
objects.description: Hooking prevents memory dumps by preventing mapping of memory into the kernel's virtual address space.

external_references.description: J. Stuttgen, M. Cohen, Anti-forensic resilient memory acquisition,

objects.name: Parent Process
objects.description: (Explorer.exe); Executing an application by a debugger will result in the parent process being the debugger process rather than the shell process (Explorer.exe) or the command line. Malware checks its parent process; if it's not explorer.exe, it's assumed to be a debugger.

objects.name: XOR
objects.description: Malware may use xor to decode data.

objects.name: Window Text
objects.description: After finding an open application window, malware gets graphical window text.

objects.name: SetHandleInformation
objects.description: (Protected Handle)

objects.name: Device Driver
objects.description: Allows kernel to access hardware connected to the system.

objects.name: System Services
objects.description: Malware may abuse system services or daemons to execute.

objects.name: HTML5 Performance Object Check
objects.description: In three browser families, it is possible to extract the frequency of the Windows performance counter frequency, using standard HTML and Javascript. This value can then be used to detect whether the code is being executed in a virtual machine, by detecting two specific frequencies commonly used in virtual but not physical machines.

objects.name: Allocate Thread Local Storage
objects.description: Malware allocates thread local storage.

objects.name: Memory Breakpoints
objects.description: (PAGE_GUARD); Guard pages trigger an exception the first time they are accessed and can be used to detect a debugger. See  for details.

objects.name: Implicit Flows
objects.description: Data is propagated via semantic relationships, for example one variable not changing its state could imply the state of another variable.

objects.name: Check Processes
objects.description: The malware may check running processes for specific strings such as "malw" to detect a analysis environment.

objects.name: SizeOfImage
objects.description: Set the SizeOfImage field of PEB.LoaderData to be huge.

objects.name: Self-Debugging
objects.description: Debug itself to prevent another debugger to be attached.

objects.name: Modify PE Header
objects.description: Any part of the header is changed or erased.

objects.name: Merged Code Sections
objects.description: Merge all sections resulting in just one entry in the sections table to make readability more difficult. May affect some detection signatures if written to be section dependent.

objects.name: Check Emulator-related Registry Keys
objects.description: Emulators register artifacts in the registry, which can be detected by malware. For example, installation of QEMU results in the registry key: *HARDWARE\DEVICEMAP\Scsi\Scsi Port 0\Scsi Bus 0\Target Id 0\Logical Unit Id 0* with value=*Identifier* and data=*QEMU*, or registry key: *HARDWARE\Description\System* with value=*SystemBiosVersion* and data=*QEMU*.

objects.name: API Hook Detection
objects.description: Module bounds based .

objects.name: Compromise Data Integrity
objects.description: Data stored on the file system of a compromised system is manipulated to compromise its integrity.

objects.name: Encrypt Data
objects.description: Malware may encrypt data.

objects.name: Import Public Key
objects.description: Malware imports a public key.

objects.name: Check Windows
objects.description: Malware may check windows for VM-related characteristics.

objects.name: Timestamp
objects.description: Malware may change the timestamp on a file to prevent detection.

objects.name: Check File and Directory Artifacts
objects.description: Virtual machines create files on the file system (e.g., VMware creates files in the installation directory C:\Program Files\VMware\VMware Tools). Malware can check the different folders to find virtual machine artifacts (e.g., Virtualbox has the artifact VBoxMouse.sys).

objects.name: On-the-Fly APIs
objects.description: Resolve API addresses before each use to prevent complete dumping.

objects.name: Two-layer Function Return
objects.description: Two layer jumping confuses tools plotting call graphs.

external_references.description: S. Shang, N. Zheng, J. Xu, M. Xu, H. Zhang, "Detecting Malware Variants via Function-call Graph Similarity," IEEE 2010 5th International Conference on Malicious and Unwanted Software, 2010.

objects.name: Indicator Blocking
objects.description: Malware blocks indicators or events that would indicate malicious activity. Methods relevant to the malware domain are below.

objects.name: Unique Hardware/Firmware Check
objects.description: Malware may check for hardware characteristics unique to being virtualized, allowing the malware to detect the virtual environment.

objects.name: Process detection
objects.description: Malware can scan for the process name associated with common analysis tools.

objects.name: Alternative ntdll.dll
objects.description: A copy of ntdll.dll is dropped to the filesystem and then loaded. This alternative DLL is used to execute function calls to evade sandboxes which use hooking in the operating system's ntdll.dll.

objects.name: Minifilter
objects.description: Malware registers a minifilter.

objects.name: Mouse Click
objects.description: Malware simulates mouse click.

objects.name: Standard Compression of Data
objects.description: Uses a standard algorithm to compress strings and variables (executable file data).

objects.name: Tiger
objects.description: Malware uses a Tiger hash.

objects.name: Code Discovery
objects.description: Malware may inspect code or enumerate aspects.

objects.name: Modern Specs Check - Total physical memory
objects.description: Different aspects of the hardware are inspected to determine whether the machine has modern characteristics. A machine with substandard specifications indicates a virtual environment. Most modern machines have at leave 4 GB of memory. (GlobalMemoryStatusEx) .

objects.name: Set Header
objects.description: HTTP header is set.

objects.name: Known Window
objects.description: Malware may detect an analysis tool via the presence of a known window.

objects.name: Bootkit
objects.description: The boot sectors of a hard drive are modified (e.g., Master Boot Record (MBR)). ATT&CK associates bootkits with the Persistence. See ATT&CK: **Pre-OS Boot: Bootkit ([T1067](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1067/))**.

objects.name: Advertisement Replacement Fraud
objects.description: Malware injects ad windows onto websites the user views.

objects.name: Alternative Installation Location
objects.description: Malware may install itself not as a file on the hard drive.

objects.name: Modern Specs Check
objects.description: Different aspects of the hardware are inspected to determine whether the machine has modern characteristics. A machine with substandard specifications indicates a virtual environment.

objects.name: QuickLZ
objects.description: Malware compresses data using QuickLZ.

objects.name: Check Running Services
objects.description: VMwareService.exe runs the VMware Tools Service as a child of services.exe. It can be identified by listing services.

objects.name: Generate Windows Exception
objects.description: Malware may trigger an exception as a way of gathering system details.

objects.name: CDROM
objects.description: The CD-ROM is modified.

objects.name: Junk Code Insertion
objects.description: Insert dummy code between relevant opcodes. Can make signature writing more complex.

objects.name: Read Virtual Disk
objects.description: Malware reads a virtual disk.

objects.name: Break Point Clearing
objects.description: Intentionally clearing software or hardware breakpoints.

objects.name: Emulator Detection
objects.description: Detects whether the malware instance is being executed inside an emulator. If so, conditional execution selects a benign execution path.

objects.name: Directory Listing
objects.description: Controller requests a directory listing from the implant, optionally from a given path, optionally recursive.

objects.name: Request Email Address List
objects.description: Request email address list.

objects.name: Input Capture
objects.description: Malware captures user input.

objects.name: Process detection - PE Utilities
objects.description: Malware can scan for the process name associated with common analysis tools. ImportREC / PETools / LordPE

objects.name: RC6
objects.description: Malware encrypts with the RC6 algorithm.

objects.name: Load Driver
objects.description: Malware loads a device driver or minifilter.

objects.name: Timing/Delay Check GetTickCount
objects.description: Malware uses GetTickCount function in a timing/delay check.

objects.name: RtlAdjustPrivilege
objects.description: Malware may call RtlAdjustPrivilege to detect if a debugger is attached (or to prevent a debugger from attaching).

objects.name: AMSI Bypass
objects.description: Malware bypasses AMSI (Anti-malware Scan Interface).

objects.name: Encode Data
objects.description: Malware may encode data.

objects.name: Modify Hardware
objects.description: Malware modifies hardware.

objects.name: Append Extension
objects.description: A new extension is appended.

objects.name: Timing/Delay Check QueryPerformanceCounter
objects.description: Malware uses QueryPerformanceCounter in a timing/delay check.

objects.name: Send File
objects.description: Send FTP file.

objects.name: Process Environment Block
objects.description: The Process Environment Block (PEB) is a Windows data structure associated with each process that contains several fields, such as "BeingDebugged," "NtGlobalFlag," and "IsDebugged". Testing the value of this PEB field of a particular process can indicate whether the process is being debugged. Testing "BeingDebugged" is equivalent to using the kernel32!IsDebuggerPresent API call (see separate method).

objects.name: Parallel Threads
objects.description: Use several parallel threads to make analysis harder.

objects.name: Cryptocurrency
objects.description: Malware accesses files that contain sensitive data or credentials related to Bitcoin and other cryptocurrency wallets.

objects.name: Executable Code Obfuscation
objects.description: Executable code can be obfuscated to hinder disassembly and static code analysis. This behavior is specific to a malware sample's executable code (data and text sections).

objects.name: Byte Stealing
objects.description: Move or copy the first bytes / instructions of the original code elsewhere. AKA stolen bytes or code splicing. For example, a packer may incorporate the first few instructions of the original EntryPoint (EP) into its unpacking stub before the tail transition in order to confuse automated unpackers and novice analysts. This can make it harder for rebuilding and may bypass breakpoints if set prematurely.

objects.name: Domain Name Generation
objects.description: Malware generates the domain name of the controller to which it connects. Access to on the fly domains enables C2 to operate as domains and IP addresses are blocked. The algorithm can be complicated in more advanced implants; understanding the details so that names can be predicted can be useful in mitigation and response.

objects.name: Anti-debugging Instructions
objects.description: Malware code contains mnemonics related to anti-debugging (e.g., rdtsc, icebp).

objects.name: Filter by Extension
objects.description: Malware may filter by extension (common in ransomware).

objects.name: Hidden Processes
objects.description: Hides processes used by the adversary or malware instance. This can involve techniques such as process list unlinking.

objects.name: Static Linking
objects.description: Copy locally the whole content of API code.

objects.name: Zcash
objects.description: Access Zcash data.

objects.name: Instruction Testing - VPCEXT
objects.description: The execution of certain x86 instructions will result in different values when executed inside of a VM instead of on bare metal. Accordingly, these can be used to detect the execution of the malware in a VM.

objects.name: Start Server
objects.description: HTTP server is started.

objects.name: Modify Policy
objects.description: Malware may modify policies to make software less effective. This is similar to ATT&CK's Subvert Trust Controls: Code Signing Policy Modification ([T1553.006](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1553/006/), [T1632.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1632/001/))

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
objects.description: Malware may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands, scripts, or binaries.

objects.name: Keylogging
objects.description: Malware captures user keyboard input.

objects.name: Create Process
objects.description: Malware creates a process.

objects.name: Automated Exfiltration
objects.description: Malware may exfiltrate data via automated processing or scripting.

objects.name: Delete Application/Software
objects.description: An application or software is deleted.

objects.name: Return Obfuscation
objects.description: Overwrite the RET address on the stack or the code at the RET address. Variation seen that writes to the start-up code or main module that called the malware's WinMain or DllMain.

objects.name: System Service Dispatch Table Hooking
objects.description: Malware (e.g. rootkit, malicious drivers) may hook the system service dispatch table (SSDT), also called the system service descriptor table. The SSDT contains information about the service tables used by the operating system for dispatching system calls. Hooking the SSDT enables malware to hide files, registry keys, and network connections.

objects.name: Registry
objects.description: Malware modifies the registry.

objects.name: Encoding-Standard Algorithm
objects.description: A standard algorithm (e.g., base64) is used to encode a malware sample, file, or other information.

objects.name: Hijack Execution Flow
objects.description: Malware may execute by hijacking the way operating systems run programs. Malware (e.g. rootkit) alters API behavior or redirects execution (i.e., hooking) to a malicious API version for a variety of purposes. Malware may use hooking to load and execute code within the context of another process, hiding execution and gaining elevated privileges and access to the process's memory. Different types of hooking are defined as methods below.

objects.name: rand
objects.description: Malware generates a pseudo-random sequence using rand.

objects.name: Create Mutex
objects.description: Malware creates a mutex to enable synchronization.

objects.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
objects.description: Malware may encrypt files stored on the system to prevent user access until a ransom is paid and/or to interrupt system availability. The encryption process usually iterates over all letter drives in the system (except for CD drives) and then recursively encrypts all files with specific suffixes.

objects.name: Check Virtual Devices
objects.description: The presence of virtual devices can indicate a virtualized environment (e.g., "\\.\VBoxTrayIPC").

objects.name: Open URL
objects.description: HTTP client connects to a URL.

objects.name: Thread Timeout
objects.description: Setting dwMilliseconds in WaitForSingleObject to a small number will timeout the thread before the analyst can step through and analyze the code executing in the thread. Modifying this via patch, register, or stack to the value `0xFFFFFFFF`, the **INFINITE** constant circumvents this anti-debugging technique.

objects.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
objects.description: Software is exploited - either because of a vulnerability or through its designed features - to gain access for malware. In general, exploitation may be done by a human attacker, but MBC focuses on software exploits implemented in code. Malware-specific details are below.

objects.name: Create TCP Socket
objects.description: A TCP socket is created.

objects.name: Illusion
objects.description: Creates an illusion; makes the analyst think something happened when it didn't.

objects.name: Force Lazy Writing
objects.description: Some operating systems will sometimes use a form of "lazy writing" for disk I/O, which may obscure the true provenance of the write operation. This method occurs when code intentionally forces the operating system to perform a lazy writing operation. For example, in Windows, a file may be opened, memory mapped, and closed, but the memory map will still exist and can be written to, which will cause a lazy write that looks like it is coming from the System process.

external_references.description: Alexander Adamov, Stealthy WastedLocker: eluding behavior blockers, but not only. Online:

objects.name: Injection via Windows Fibers
objects.description: Malware executes shellcode via Windows fibers by converting a thread to a fiber.

objects.name: OutputDebugString
objects.description: (GetLastError); The OutputDebugString function will demonstrate different behavior depending whether or not a debugger is present. See  for details.

objects.name: FNV
objects.description: Malware uses the FNV hash function.

objects.name: Interprocess Communication
objects.description: The Interprocess Communication micro-behavior focuses on interprocess communication.

objects.name: Block Interrupts
objects.description: Block interrupt (via hooking) 1 and/or 3 to prevent debuggers from working.

objects.name: RC4
objects.description: Malware decrypts data encrypted with the RC4 algorithm.

objects.name: Hypervisor/Virtualized Rootkit
objects.description: A hypervisor (virtualized) rootkit hosts the target operating system as a virtual machine, enabling interception of all hardware calls. Also called, virtual-machine-based rootkit (VMBR).

objects.name: Bootloader
objects.description: A bootloader rootkit modifies the bootloader, enabling activation before the operating system is started. Also known as a Bootkit. See ATT&CK: [Bootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1542/003/).

objects.name: Erase the PE header
objects.description: Erase PE header from memory.

objects.name: Heap Spray
objects.description: Malware may use heap spraying to write a sequence of bytes on the heap section of a process.

objects.name: Set Thread Local Storage Value
objects.description: Malware allocates thread local storage.

objects.name: VMProtect
objects.description: Uses VMProtect.

objects.name: Log File
objects.description: Malware may look for system log files.

objects.name: RSA
objects.description: Malware encrypts with the RSA algorithm.

objects.name: Custom Compression of Data
objects.description: Uses a custom algorithm to compress strings and variables (executable file data).

objects.name: File search
objects.description: Controller requests the implant to search for a given filename pattern, often a [glob](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glob_(programming)).

objects.name: Injected DLL Testing
objects.description: Testing for the name of a particular DLL that is known to be injected by a sandbox for API hooking is a common way of detecting sandbox environments. This can be achieved through the kernel32!GetModuleHandle API call and other means.

objects.name: Check Files
objects.description: Sandboxes create files on the file system. Malware can check the different folders to find sandbox artifacts.

objects.name: Check for Payload
objects.description: An implant may check with the controller for additional payloads or instructions, sometimes at a regular interval. This is also known as beaconing.

objects.name: CRC32
objects.description: Malware computes a CRC32 checksum.

objects.name: InternetOpen
objects.description: Initializes an application's use of the WinINet functions.

objects.name: Monitoring Thread
objects.description: Malware may spawn a monitoring thread to detect tampering, breakpoints, etc.

objects.name: Send Response
objects.description: HTTP server sends response.

objects.name: AES
objects.description: Malware encrypts with the AES algorithm.

objects.name: IEncodingFilterFactory
objects.description: Malware decompresses data using IEncodingFilterFactory.

objects.name: Set File Attributes
objects.description: Malware sets or modifies the attributes of a file.

objects.name: Multiple Stages of Loaders
objects.description: Multiple stages of loaders are used with an encoded payload.

objects.name: Nanomites
objects.description: int3 with code replacement table; debugs itself.

objects.name: Disk Wipe
objects.description: Malware may erase the content of storage devices. This behavior is different than **Data Destruction ([E1485](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/v2.3/impact/data-destruction.md))** because sections of the disk are erased rather than individual files.

objects.name: Click Hijacking
objects.description: Malware alters DNS server settings to route to a rogue DNS server: when the user clicks on a search result link displayed through a search engine query, malware re-routes the user to different website. Instead of going to the requested site, the user is taken to an alternate website such that the click triggers payment to the threat actor.

objects.name: Query Registry Key
objects.description: Malware queries a registry key.

objects.name: Change SizeOfImage
objects.description: Changing this value during run time can prevent some debuggers from attaching. Also confuses some unpackers and dumpers.

objects.name: Hook Interrupt
objects.description: Modification of interrupt vector or descriptor tables.

objects.name: Arbitrary Memory Corruption
objects.description: Data is propagated by corrupting memory, for example overwriting a region of stack space where a file pointer is held.

objects.name: Bypass Windows File Protection
objects.description: Malware bypasses Windows file protection.

objects.name: Static Public Library
objects.description: A public crypto library is embedded in the code.

objects.name: Open Thread
objects.description: Malware opens a thread.

objects.name: Injection using Shims
objects.description: Malware may use shims to target an executable (shims are a way of hooking into APIs and targeting specific executables and are provided by Microsoft for backward compatibility, allowing developers to apply program fixes without rewriting code).

objects.name: Interruption
objects.description: If an interruption is mishandled by the debugger, it can cause a single-byte instruction to be inadvertently skipped, which can be detected by malware. Examples include Interrupt 0x2d and Interrupt 1 [7].

objects.name: Server
objects.description: General HTTP server behavior.

objects.name: InternetReadFile
objects.description: Reads data from an open Internet file (URL data).

objects.name: Process Injection
objects.description: Malware may execute code in the address space of a separate process.

objects.name: Import Obfuscation
objects.description: Add obfuscation between imports calls and APIs.

objects.name: Server Connect
objects.description: Connects to DNS server.

objects.name: Encoding - Standard Encoding
objects.description: Data is encoded. A standard algorithm, such as base64 encoding, is used to encode the exfiltrated data.

objects.name: API Call
objects.description: Malware uses crypto API calls.

objects.name: Encryption of Code
objects.description: A file's executable code is encrypted, but not necessarily the file's data.

objects.name: Send Poisoned Text Message
objects.description: A malicious attachment is sent via spam SMS or MMS messages. When the user clicks the link, malware is installed.

objects.name: Conditional Execution
objects.description: Malware checks system environment conditions or characteristics to determine execution path. For example, malware may not run or be dormant unless system conditions are right, or file that is dropped may vary according to execution environment. Conditional execution in malware happens autonomously, not because of an attacker's command.

objects.name: Terminate Thread
objects.description: Malware terminates a thread.

objects.name: Environment Variable
objects.description: Malware modifies environment variables.

objects.name: Disassembler Evasion
objects.description: Malware code evades disassembly in a recursive or linear disassembler. Some methods apply to both types of disassemblers; others apply to one type and not the other.

objects.name: Get Base Indirectly
objects.description: CALL to a POP; finds base of code or data, often the packed version of the code; also used often in obfuscated/packed shellcode.

objects.name: Alter File Extension
objects.description: Malware alters a file extension. This could be done for many reasons, including to hide the file or as part of a ransomware's encryption process.

objects.name: Process Environment Block NtGlobalFlag
objects.description: The NtGlobalFlag field is tested to determine whether the process is being debugged.

objects.name: Debugger Evasion
objects.description: Behaviors that make debugging difficult.

objects.name: Receive TCP Data
objects.description: Receive TCP data.

objects.name: Application Window Discovery
objects.description: Malware may attempt to get a listing of open application windows.

objects.name: Procedure Hooking
objects.description: Intercepts and executes designated code in response to events such as messages, keystrokes, and mouse inputs.

objects.name: Hashed Message Authentication Code
objects.description: Malware uses a hashed message authentication code (HMAC) schema.

objects.name: aPLib
objects.description: Malware decompresses data using aPLib.

objects.name: File Transfer Protocol (FTP) Servers
objects.description: Malware leverages an FTP server.

objects.name: Receive UDP Data
objects.description: Receive UDP data.

objects.name: Read Header
objects.description: HTTP read header.

objects.name: Create Process via Shellcode
objects.description: Malware uses shellcode to create a process.

objects.name: Stream Cipher
objects.description: Malware decrypts data encrypted with a stream cipher.

objects.name: Shutdown Event
objects.description: Malware can register the shutdown event triggered by WinLogon to allow a malicious DLL to execute every time the machine shuts down: when the machine is shutdown the malware will be loaded into memory; then it will download the primary malware and reinfect the machine. The malware will also lie dormant during incident reporting processes. To check whether malware has registered for login events, check the registry key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINESoftwareMicrosoftWindows NTCurrentVersionWinlogonNotify. If a subkey with any name exists and it has a "shutdown" value then the dll in the "DLLName" key will be launched during the shutdown process.

objects.name: Encoding
objects.description: Data is encoded.

objects.name: SHA256
objects.description: Malware uses a SHA-256 hash.

objects.name: Invoke NTDLL System Calls via Encoded Table
objects.description: Invokes ntdll.dll functions without using an export table; an encoded translation table on the stack is used instead.

external_references.description: S. Shang, N. Zheng, J. Xu, M. Xu, H. Zhang, "Detecting Malware Variants via Function-call Graph Similarity," IEEE 2010 5th International Conference on Malicious and Unwanted Software, 2010.

objects.name: Pre-Debug
objects.description: Prevents debugger from attaching to process or to break until after the code of interest has been executed.

objects.name: Router Firmware
objects.description: Cisco routers can have their firmware images modified in order to maliciously infect and persist on end-user machines in a network. This is accomplished by using default or acquired credentials to gain access to a router and to install a backdoor. The implant resides within a modified Cisco IOS image and, when loaded, maintains its persistence in the environment, even after a system reboot. However, any further modules loaded by the attacker will only exist in the router's volatile memory and will not be available for use after reboot. Known affected hardware includes Cisco routers 1841, 2811, and 3825.

objects.name: Disable System File Overwrite Protection
objects.description: Disables system file overwrite protection mechanisms such as Windows file protection, thereby enabling system files to be modified or replaced.

objects.name: Fast-Hash
objects.description: Malware uses the Fast-Hash hash function.

objects.name: Extract Body
objects.description: HTTP client extracts HTTP body.

objects.name: Conditional Misdirection
objects.description: Conditional jumps are sometimes used to confuse disassembly engines, resulting in the wrong instruction boundaries and thus wrong mnemonic and operands; identified by instructions *jmp/jcc to a label+#* (e.g., JNE loc_401345fe+2).

objects.name: Data Destruction
objects.description: Data, system files, or other files are destroyed. Individual files are selected, as opposed to wiping an entire sector.

objects.name: TIB Aware
objects.description: Malware may access information in the Thread Information Block (TIB) for debug detection or process obfuscation detection. The TIB can be accessed as an offset of the segment register (e.g., fs:[20h]).

objects.name: Check Named System Objects
objects.description: Virtual machines often include specific named system objects by default, such as Windows device drivers, which can be detected by testing for specific strings, whether found in the Windows registry or other places.

objects.name: Sosemanuk
objects.description: Malware decrypts data encrypted with the Sosemanuk stream cipher.

objects.name: Themida
objects.description: Uses Themida.

objects.name: Set Registry Key
objects.description: Malware sets a registry key.

objects.name: Hide Artifacts
objects.description: Malware may hide artifacts to evade detection and/or to persist on the system. See potential methods related to malware below.

objects.name: Receive Data
objects.description: Receive data or command from a controller.

objects.name: Different Opcode Sets
objects.description: Use different opcodes sets (ex: FPU, MMX, SSE) to block emulators.

objects.name: RtlAdjustPrivilege
objects.description: Calling RtlAdjustPrivilege to either prevent a debugger from attaching or to detect if a debugger is attached.

objects.name: Disable Code Integrity
objects.description: Malware disables Code Integrity driver.

objects.name: Modify Registry
objects.description: Malware may make changes to the Windows Registry to hide execution or to persist on the system (note that ATT&CK does not extend this behavior to the Persistence objective).

objects.name: Supply Chain Compromise
objects.description: The supply chain may be compromised to enable initial malware infection. MBC objectives don't encompass initial infection, but the malware-related methods are listed below supplement the information available defined in ATT&CK and allow for lateral movement: **Supply Chain Compromise ([T1195](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1195/), [T1474](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1474/))**.

objects.name: Copy File
objects.description: Malware copies a file.

objects.name: Request
objects.description: Makes SMTP request.

objects.name: Ransom Note
objects.description: Ransomware displays a ransom note. Ransom notes are sometimes used to link instances of ransomware, even when the code or anti-analysis techniques change.

objects.name: Instruction Testing - SMSW
objects.description: The execution of certain x86 instructions will result in different values when executed inside of a VM instead of on bare metal. Accordingly, these can be used to detect the execution of the malware in a VM.

objects.name: Process Environment Block IsDebugged
objects.description: The IsDebugged field is tested to determine whether the process is being debugged.

objects.name: HC-128
objects.description: Malware decrypts data encrypted with the HC-128 algorithm.

objects.name: VBA Stomping
objects.description: Typically, VBA source code is compiled into p-code, which is stored with compressed sourced code in the OLE file with VBA macros. VBA Stomping - when the VBA source code is removed and only the p-code remains - makes analysis much harder. See  for an analysis of a VBA-Stomped malicious VBA Office document. See  for information on Evil Clippy, a tool that creates malicious MS Office documents.

objects.name: Snefru
objects.description: Malware uses a Snefru hash.

objects.name: Delete Shadow Copies
objects.description: Deletes shadow drive data, which is related to ransomware.

objects.name: Overflow Buffer
objects.description: Malware may overflow the buffer for various purposes.

objects.name: Instruction Testing - SGDT/SLDT (no pill)
objects.description: The execution of certain x86 instructions will result in different values when executed inside of a VM instead of on bare metal. Accordingly, these can be used to detect the execution of the malware in a VM.  The No Pill technique relies on the fact that the LDT structure is assigned to a processor not an Operating System. The LDT location on a host machine will be zero and on a virtual machine will be non-zero.

objects.name: Query Registry Value
objects.description: Malware queries a registry value.

objects.name: WinINet
objects.description: Send FTP command via WinINet.

objects.name: Start Interactive Shell
objects.description: Start an interactive shell using a built-in program (e.g. cmd.exe, PowerShell, bash). This is often implemented with polling the network connection from the controller for text commands to redirect to the shell's stdin and polling the shell's stdout and stderr to redirect over the network to the controller. This differs from Execute Shell Command because the shell process runs across multiple iterations of the recv-command(s)-send-result loop.

objects.name: Malloc Use
objects.description: Instead of unpacking into a pre-defined section/segment (ex: .text) of the binary, use malloc() / VirtualAlloc() to create a new segment. This makes keeping track of memory locations across different runs more difficult, as there is no guarantee that malloc/VirtualAlloc will assign the same address range each time.

objects.name: Application Rootkit
objects.description: Application rootkits operate by exchanging standard application files with rootkit files, or changing applications by injecting code or patching.

objects.name: Create Ransomware File
objects.description: Create a file used by ransomware.

objects.name: Executable Heap
objects.description: The heap is made executable.

objects.name: SHA1
objects.description: Malware uses a SHA-1 hash.

objects.name: Check String
objects.description: Malware may check a string for some characteristics, such as being ascii content; credit card number; or length.

objects.name: Relocate API Code
objects.description: Relocate API code in separate buffer (calls don’t lead to imported DLLs).

objects.name: SeDebugPrivilege
objects.description: (Csrss.exe); Using the OpenProcess function on the csrss.exe process can detect a debugger.

objects.name: Writes File
objects.description: Malware writes to a file.  Writing to a file enables file modification.

objects.name: Exfiltrate via File Hosting Service
objects.description: Malware may exfiltrate files to a file hosting location.

objects.name: System Information Discovery
objects.description: Malware may attempt to get detailed information about the system.

objects.name: Printer
objects.description: The printer is modified.

objects.name: SMTP Connection Discovery
objects.description: Malware may test whether an outgoing SMTP connection can be made from the system on which the malware instance is executing to some SMTP server, by sending a test SMTP transaction.

objects.name: Use API
objects.description: Malware generates a pseudo-random sequence using a Windows API.

objects.name: Twofish
objects.description: Malware encrypts with the Twofish algorithm.

objects.name: Exploit Kit
objects.description: An Exploit Kit is a toolkit that exploits vulnerabilities in software to deliver malicious payloads (malware).

objects.name: Free Memory
objects.description: Malware may free memory.

objects.name: Guest Process Testing
objects.description: Virtual machines offer guest additions that can be installed to add functionality such as clipboard sharing. Detecting the process responsible for these tasks, via its name or other methods, is a technique employed by malware for detecting whether it is being executed in a virtual machine.

objects.name: CloseHandle
objects.description: (NtClose); If an invalid handle is passed to the CloseHandle function and a debugger is present, then an EXCEPTION_INVALID_HANDLE (0xC0000008) exception will be raised.

objects.name: Symbol Obfuscation
objects.description: Remove or rename symbolic information commonly inserted by compilers for debugging purposes.

objects.name: Receive Data
objects.description: Receive data on socket.

objects.name: Flow Opcode Obstruction
objects.description: Flow opcodes (e.g., jumps, loops) are removed and emulated (or decrypted) by the packer during execution, resulting in incorrect dumps. .

objects.name: Move File
objects.description: Malware moves a file.

objects.name: Remote Commands
objects.description: Malware may provide an attacker with explicit commands. This behavior differs from the **Remote Access ([B0022](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/v2.3/impact/remote-access.md))** behavior under the [Impact](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/v2.3/impact) objective in that *Impact: Remote Access* is potentially much broader and may include full remote access.

objects.name: Process detection - Debuggers
objects.description: Malware can scan for the process name associated with common analysis tools. OllyDBG / ImmunityDebugger / WinDbg / IDA Pro

objects.name: Heavens Gate
objects.description: Malware evades endpoint security products by invoking 64-bit code in 32-bit processes, effectively bypassing user-mode hooks.

objects.name: Registry Install
objects.description: Stores itself in the Windows registry.

objects.name: Check Processes
objects.description: The VMware Tools use processes like VMwareServices.exe or VMwareTray.exe, to perform actions on the virtual environment. Malware can list the process and searches for the VMware string. Process related to Virtualbox can be detected by malware by query the process list.

objects.name: Request Email Template
objects.description: Request email template.

objects.name: Set Variable
objects.description: Malware sets an environment variable.

objects.name: NtQueryInformationProcess
objects.description: Calling NtQueryInformationProcess with its ProcessInformationClass parameter set to 0x07 (ProcessDebugPort constant) will cause the system to set ProcessInformation to -1 if the process is being debugged. Calling with ProcessInformationClass set to 0x0E (ProcessDebugFlags) or 0x11 (ProcessDebugObject) are used similarly. Testing "ProcessDebugPort" is equivalent to using the kernel32!CheckRemoteDebuggerPresent API call (see next method).

objects.name: Jump/Call Absolute Address
objects.description: Relative operands of jumps and calls into are made absolute (better compression). May confuse some basic block detection algorithms.

objects.name: ROP Chains
objects.description: Return-Oriented Programming can be used to bypass DEP. It can also be used to bypass code signing.

objects.name: Application Hook
objects.description: Keystrokes are captured with an application hook.

objects.name: Create Process via WMI
objects.description: Malware uses WMI to create a process.

objects.name: Base64
objects.description: Malware may encode data using Base64.

objects.name: Block Cipher
objects.description: Malware encrypts with a block cipher.

objects.name: Simulate Hardware
objects.description: Malware simulates hardware.

objects.name: Hook Injection via SetWindowsHooksEx
objects.description: Malware can leverage hooking functionality to have its malicious DLL loaded upon an event getting triggered in a specific thread, which is usually done by calling SetWindowsHookEx to install a hook routine into the hook chain.

objects.name: HC-256
objects.description: Malware decrypts data encrypted with the HC-256 algorithm.

objects.name: Open Registry Key
objects.description: Malware opens a registry key.

objects.name: Server to Client File Transfer
objects.description: File is transferred from controller to implant.

objects.name: Stream Cipher
objects.description: Malware encrypts with a stream cipher.

objects.name: Decode Data
objects.description: Malware may decode data.

objects.name: Import Address Table Obfuscation
objects.description: Obfuscate the import address table.

objects.name: Fake Code Insertion
objects.description: Add fake code similar to known packers or known goods to fool identification. Can confuse some automated unpackers.

objects.name: Data Value Obfuscation
objects.description: Obfuscate data values through indirection of local or global variables. For example, the instruction *if (a == 0) do x* can be obfuscated by setting a global variable, *Z*, to zero and using it in the instruction: *if (a==Z) do x*.  [NEEDS REVIEW]

objects.name: Control Dependence
objects.description: Data is propagated via an if-then-else clause instead of direct assignment.

objects.name: Get Variable
objects.description: Malware gets an environment variable.

objects.name: WinAPI
objects.description: Screen is captured using WinAPI functions (e.g., user32.GetDesktopWindow).

objects.name: UPX
objects.description: Uses UPX packer.

objects.name: Receive Request
objects.description: HTTP server receives request.

objects.name: Instruction Testing - IN
objects.description: The execution of certain x86 instructions will result in different values when executed inside of a VM instead of on bare metal. Accordingly, these can be used to detect the execution of the malware in a VM.

objects.name: RC4
objects.description: Malware encrypts with the RC4 algorithm.

objects.name: NtSetInformationThread
objects.description: Calling this API with a fake class length or thread handle can indicate whether it is hooked. After calling NtSetInformationThread properly, the HideThreadFromDebugger flag is checked with the NtQueryInformationThread API.

objects.name: Console
objects.description: Malware modifies the console.

objects.name: Taskbar Discovery
objects.description: Malware may find the taskbar.

objects.name: Minification
objects.description: Minification is 'the process of removing all unnecessary characters from source code without changing its functionality.'  A simple example is when all the unnecessary whitespace and comments are removed. Minification is distinguished from compression in that it neither adds to nor changes the code seen by the interpreter. Minification is often used for malware written in interpreted languages, such as JavaScript, PHP, or Python. Legitimate code that is transmitted many times a second, such as JavaScript on websites, often uses minification to simply reduce the number of bytes transmitted.

objects.name: Structured Exception Handling (SEH)
objects.description: A portion of the code always generates an exception so that malicious code is executed with the exception handling. See  .

objects.name: Connect Socket
objects.description: A server or client connects via a TCP socket.

objects.name: Hidden Kernel Modules
objects.description: Hides the use of kernel modules by the malware instance (e.g. rootkit). Techniques include kernel module list unlinking.

objects.name: Open Process
objects.description: Malware opens a process.

objects.name: SHA224
objects.description: Malware uses a SHA-224 hash.

objects.name: Test API Routines
objects.description: Calls Windows API routines with invalid arguments to identify error supression.

objects.name: Human User Check
objects.description: Detects whether there is any "user" activity on the machine, such as the movement of the mouse cursor, non-default wallpaper, or recently opened Office files. Directories or file might be counted. If there is no human activity, the machine is suspected to be a virtualized machine and/or sandbox. Other items used to detect a user: mouse clicks (single/double), DialogBox, scrolling, color of background pixel . This method is similar to ATT&CK's [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion: User Activity Based Checks](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497/002/) sub-technique.

objects.name: Install Additional Program
objects.description: Installs another, different program on the system. The additional program can be any secondary module; examples include backdoors, malicious drivers, kernel modules, and OS X Apps.

objects.name: Memory Rootkit
objects.description: A memory rootkit hids in RAM. Behaviors may include methods to prevent memory access. The lifespan of a memory rootkit is short because it disappears after a system reboot.

objects.name: Windows Utilities
objects.description: One or more Windows utilities are used.

objects.name: Modern Specs Check - Printer
objects.description: Different aspects of the hardware are inspected to determine whether the machine has modern characteristics. A machine with substandard specifications indicates a virtual environment. Checks whether there is a potential connected printer or default Windows printers; if not a virtual environment is suspected.

objects.name: Process detection - SysInternals Suite Tools
objects.description: Malware can scan for the process name associated with common analysis tools. Process Explorer / Process Monitor / Regmon / Filemon, TCPView, Autoruns

objects.name: Send Data
objects.description: HTTP clients sends data to a server (POST/PUT).

objects.name: Socket Communication
objects.description: This micro-behavior focuses on socket (TCP, UDP) communication.

objects.name: ICMP Communication
objects.description: This micro-behavior is related to ICMP communication.

objects.name: Luhn
objects.description: Malware uses Luhn algorithm, often to validate identification numbers (e.g, credit card number).

objects.name: WinINet
objects.description: The Windows Internet (WinINet) application programming interface (API) is used by malware to interact with FTP and HTTP protocols to access Internet resources.

objects.name: Client
objects.description: General HTTP client behavior.

objects.name: NtQueryObject
objects.description: The ObjectTypeInformation and ObjectAllTypesInformation flags are checked for debugger detection.

objects.name: Send System Information
objects.description: Implant sends system information.

objects.name: Synchronization
objects.description: Malware enables two or more processes/threads to share a resource.

objects.name: Kernel Modules and Extensions
objects.description: Malware may use loadable kernel modules to persist on a system. For example, one type of module is the device driver, which allows the kernel to access hardware connected to the system. Malware may try to hide drivers or modules by creating them without a name.

objects.name: Checksum
objects.description: Malware may derive a checksum from some block of data. The checksum is often used for data validation.

objects.name: Hidden Files and Directories
objects.description: Malware may hide files and folders to avoid detection and/or to persist on the system. See potential methods below.

objects.name: Unique Hardware/Firmware Check - MAC Address
objects.description: Malware may check for hardware characteristics unique to being virtualized, allowing the malware to detect the virtual environment. VMware uses specific virtual MAC address that can be detected. The usual MAC address used started with the following numbers: "00:0C:29", "00:1C:14", "00:50:56", "00:05:69". Virtualbox uses specific virtual MAC address that can be detected by Malware. The usual MAC address used started with the following numbers: 08:00:27.

objects.name: ProcessHeap
objects.description: Process heaps are affected by debuggers. Malware can detect a debugger by checking heap header fields such as Flags (debugger present if value greater than 2) or ForceFlags (debugger present if value greater than 0).

objects.name: Disable Kernel Patch Protection
objects.description: Bypasses or disables kernel patch protection mechanisms such as Windows' PatchGuard, enabling the malware instance to operate at the same level as the operating system kernel and kernel mode drivers (KMD).

objects.name: Delete Registry Value
objects.description: Malware deletes a registry value.

objects.name: Abuse Windows Function Calls
objects.description: Malware abuses native Windows function calls to transfer execution to shellcode that it loads into memory. A pointer to the callback function is used to supply the memory address of the shellcode. Functions that can be abused include EnumResourceTypesA and EnumUILanguagesW.

objects.name: DNS Communication
objects.description: The DNS Communication micro-behavior focuses on DNS communication.

objects.name: Enumerate Threads
objects.description: Malware enumerates threads.

objects.name: Hardware Breakpoints
objects.description: (SEH/GetThreadContext); Debug registers will indicate the presence of a debugger. See  for details.

objects.name: Unhook APIs
objects.description: Security products may hook APIs to monitor the behavior of malware. To avoid being found, malware may load DLLs in memory and overwrite their bytes.

objects.name: Process Environment Block BeingDebugged
objects.description: The BeingDebugged field is tested to determine whether the process is being debugged.

objects.name: Encryption - Standard Encryption
objects.description: Data is encrypted. A standard algorithm, such as Rijndael/AES, DES, RC4, is used to encrypt the exfiltrated data.

objects.name: Malicious Network Driver
objects.description: Malicious network drivers can be installed on several machines on a network via an exploited server with high uptime. Once the drivers are installed on the host machines, they can re-infect the server if it is restarted (persistence), can infect other machines on the network (lateral movement), and can redirect traffic on the network.

objects.name: Check Registry Keys
objects.description: Virtual machines register artifacts in the registry, which can be detected by malware. For example, a search for "VMware" or "VBOX" in the registry might reveal keys that include information about a virtual hard drive, adapters, running services, or virtual mouse.  Example registry key value artifacts include "HARDWARE\Description\System (SystemBiosVersion) (VBOX)" and "SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Control\SystemInformation (SystemManufacturer) (VMWARE)"; example registry key artifacts include "SOFTWARE\VMware, Inc.\VMware Tools (VMWARE)" and "SOFTWARE\Oracle\VirtualBox Guest Additions (VBOX)".

objects.name: WinINet
objects.description: A HTTP request is made via the Windows Internet (WinINet) application programming interface (API). A specific function can be specified as a method on the [WinInet](../communication/wininet.md) microbehavior.

objects.name: File and Directory Discovery
objects.description: Malware may enumerate files and directories or may search for specific files or in specific locations.

objects.name: Inlining
objects.description: Variation of static linking where full API code inserted everywhere it would have been called.

objects.name: Decompress Data
objects.description: Malware may decompress data.

objects.name: Check Software
objects.description: Malware may check software version; for example, to determine whether the software is relatively current.

objects.name: Delete File
objects.description: Malware deletes a file.

objects.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
objects.description: Malware may add an entry to the Windows Registry run keys or startup folder to enable persistence.

objects.name: Read File
objects.description: Malware reads a file.

objects.name: Human User Check
objects.description: Detects whether there is any "user" activity on the machine, such as the movement of the mouse cursor, non-default wallpaper, or recently opened Office files. Directories or file might be counted. If there is no human activity, the machine is suspected to be a virtualized machine and/or sandbox. Other items used to detect a user: mouse clicks (single/double), DialogBox, scrolling, color of background pixel, change in foreground window . This method is very similar to ATT&CK's [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion: User Activity Based Checks](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497/002/) sub-technique.

objects.name: Product Key/ID Testing
objects.description: Checking for a particular product key/ID associated with a sandbox environment (commonly associated with the Windows host OS used in the environment) can be used to detect whether a malware instance is being executed in a particular sandbox. This can be achieved through several means, including testing for the Key/ID in the Windows registry.

objects.name: Tampering
objects.description: Erase or corrupt specific file parts to prevent rebuilding (header, packer stub, etc.).

objects.name: Encryption-Custom Algorithm
objects.description: A custom algorithm is used to encrypt a malware sample, file, or other information.

objects.name: Suspend Thread
objects.description: Malware may suspend a thread.

objects.name: Modulo
objects.description: Malware calculates a modulo value.

objects.name: Hardware/Firmware Rootkit
objects.description: A firmware rootkit compromises hardware (e.g. network card, hard drive), system BIOS, UEFI firmware. LoJack is the first in-the-wild UEFI rootkit. See ATT&CK: [System Firmware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1542/001/).

objects.name: Argument Obfuscation
objects.description: Simple number or string arguments to API calls are calculated at runtime, making linear disassembly more difficult.

objects.name: Data Flow Analysis Evasion
objects.description: Malware code evades data flow analysis (also known as information flow analysis and taint-tracking).

objects.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
objects.description: Malware may copy files from an external system to a system on a compromised network.

objects.name: Hidden Services
objects.description: Hides any system services that the malware instance creates or injects itself into. Services can be hidden by hiding associated registry keys.

objects.name: MurmurHash
objects.description: Malware uses the MurmurHash hash function.

objects.name: Fileless Malware
objects.description: Stores itself in memory.

objects.name: Thunk Code Insertion
objects.description: Variation on Jump Insertion. Used by some compilers for user-generated functions.

objects.name: Get Response
objects.description: HTTP client receives response.

objects.name: Send Data
objects.description: Send data to a controller.

objects.name: Executable Code Optimization
objects.description: Code is optimized, making it harder to statically analyze.

objects.name: Check Windows - Window size
objects.description: Malware may check windows for VM-related characteristics. Tiny window size may indicate a VM.

objects.name: dhash
objects.description: Malware uses the dhash hash function.

objects.name: Camellia
objects.description: Malware decrypts data encrypted with the Camellia algorithm.

objects.name: InternetWriteFile
objects.description: Writes data to an open Internet file.

objects.name: Encryption of Data
objects.description: A file's data is encrypted, but not necessarily the file's code.

objects.name: Send TCP Data
objects.description: Send TCP data.

objects.name: Guard Pages
objects.description: Encrypt blocks of code individually and decrypt temporarily only upon execution.

objects.name: Exploit Private APIs
objects.description: Malware can exploit private APIs to infect jailbroken and non-jailbroken iOS devices. Research shows that over 100 apps in the App Store have abused private APIs and bypassed Apple’s strict code review.

objects.name: Abuse Enterprise Certificates
objects.description: Abusing enterprise certificates enables malware to exploit private APIs and infect a wide range of users (see *Exploit Private APIs* below).

objects.name: Crypto Constant
objects.description: The malware contains a known crypto constant.

objects.name: Execution Dependency
objects.description: Software may require certain run-time or library dependencies consistent with normal software development and deployment. For example, software may require the presence of a .NET or Java runtime or to be run by a webserver that supports PHP. Unlike in **Conditional Execution ([B0025](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/v2.3/execution/conditional-execution.md))** this dependency is not because of an explicit check coded into the malware by the author.

objects.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
objects.description: Malware may make files or information difficult to discover or analyze by encoding, encrypting, or otherwise obfuscating the content. In addition, a malware sample itself can be encoded or encrypted (i.e., encoding/encryption is a code characteristic).

objects.name: User Execution
objects.description: Malware may include code that relies on specific actions by a user to execute. Note that this MBC behavior differs from [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204) in that it does do not include direct code execution (user action for *initial* execution) - MBC does not encompass ATT&CK's Initial Access Tactic.

objects.name: Password Cracking
objects.description: Consume system resources for the purpose of password cracking.

objects.name: Environmental Keys
objects.description: Malware reads certain attributes of the system (BIOS version string, hostname, MAC address, etc.) and encrypts/decrypts portions of its code or data using those attributes as input, thus preventing itself from being run on an unintended system (e.g., sandbox, emulator, etc.). Also see Deposited Keys Method. The subsequently defined ATT&CK sub-technique [Execution Guardrails: Environmental Keying (T1480.001)](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1480/001/) is related to this MBC method.

objects.name: RC4 KSA
objects.description: Malware uses the RC4 Key Scheduling Algorithm (KSA).

objects.name: Change Memory Protection
objects.description: Malware may change memory protection. For example, read-write memory may be changed to read-execute. Changing memory protection may exploits (e.g., bypass Data Execution Prevention).

objects.name: Empty Recycle Bin
objects.description: Empties the recycle bin, which can be related to ransomware.

objects.name: Instruction Testing - CPUID
objects.description: The execution of certain x86 instructions will result in different values when executed inside of a VM instead of on bare metal. Accordingly, these can be used to detect the execution of the malware in a VM.  Checking the CPU ID found within the registry can provide information to system type.

objects.name: Create File
objects.description: Malware creates a file.

objects.name: API Hashing
objects.description: Instead of storing function names in the Import Address Table (IAT) and calling GetProcAddress, a DLL is loaded and the name of each of its exports is hashed until it matches a specific hash. Manual symbol resolution is then used to access and execute the exported function. This method is often used by shellcode because it reduces the size of each import from a human-readable string to a sequence of four bytes. The Method is also known as "Imports by Hash" and "GET_APIS_WITH_CRC."

objects.name: Mouse Events
objects.description: Mouse events are captured.

objects.name: Cryptojacking
objects.description: Consume system resources to mine for cryptocurrency (e.g., Bitcoin, Litecoin, etc.).

objects.name: Initialize Winsock Library
objects.description: Winsock is initialized for TCP communication.

objects.name: Deposited Keys
objects.description: Parts of the code and/or data is encrypted or otherwise relies on data external to the file itself. For example, malware that contains code that is encrypted with a key that is downloaded from a server; malware that only runs if certain other software is installed on the system. Also see Environmental Keys Method.

objects.name: Custom Compression
objects.description: Uses a custom algorithm to compress an executable file.

objects.name: Self Discovery
objects.description: Malware may gather information about itself, such as its filename or size on disk.

objects.name: UnhandledExceptionFilter
objects.description: The UnhandledExceptionFilter function is called if no registered exception handlers exist, but it will not be reached if a debugger is present. See  for details.

objects.name: Reverse Shell
objects.description: Malware may create a reverse shell. For example, malware can invoke cmd.exe and create three pipes (stdin, stdout, stderr) to forward data between cmd.exe and an adversary.

objects.name: Software Packing
objects.description: This code characteristic - Software Packing - can make static and behavioral analysis difficult and includes packing with software protectors, such as Themida and Armadillo [[1]](#1). Methods related to anti-analysis are below. This behavior covers both characteristics of the malware (i.e., how it is packed) as well as behaviors of the malware (e.g., the malware packs another executable file).

external_references.description: Jiang Ming et al, Towards Paving the Way for Large-Scale Windows Malware Analysis: Generic Binary Unpacking with Orders-of-Magnitude Performance Boost, October 2018,

objects.name: Stolen API Code
objects.description: A variation of "byte stealing" where the first few instructions or bytes of an API are executed in user code, allowing the IAT to point into the middle of an API function. This confuses IAT rebuilders such as ImpRec and Scylla and may bypass breakpoints.

objects.name: 3DES
objects.description: Malware encrypts with the 3DES algorithm.

objects.name: Instruction Testing - VMCPUID
objects.description: The execution of certain x86 instructions will result in different values when executed inside of a VM instead of on bare metal. Accordingly, these can be used to detect the execution of the malware in a VM.

objects.name: Suicide Exit
objects.description: Malware terminates its execution based on a trigger condition or value (or because it has completed).

objects.name: Stack Pivot
objects.description: Stack pivoting involves pointing the stack pointer to an attacker-owned buffer, such as the heap, and facilitates exploits such as ROP-based exploits (see [Bypass DEP](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/v2.3/defense-evasion/bypass-data-execution-prevention.md) behavior).

objects.name: Server Connect
objects.description: Connects to an smtp server.

objects.name: Host Fingerprint Check
objects.description: Compare a previously computed host fingerprint(e.g., based on installed applications) to the current system's to determine if the malware instance is still executing on the same system. If not, execution stops, making debugging or sandbox analysis more difficult.

objects.name: Base64
objects.description: Malware may decode data using Base64.

objects.name: Check Clipboard Data
objects.description: Checks clipboard data which can be used to detect whether execution is inside a sandbox.

objects.name: Modify Existing Service
objects.description: Malware may modify an existing service to gain persistence. Modification may include disabling a service.

objects.name: Extra Loops/Time Locks
objects.description: Add extra loops to make time-constraint emulators give up.

objects.name: Install Certificate
